awd_titl_txt: CAREER: First Principles-Enabled Prediction of Thermal Conductivity and Radiative Properties of Solids
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Xiulin Ruan, Purdue University
Proposal Number: CBET-1150948

The proposed effort will enable the prediction of thermal conductive and radiative properties of solids from first principles. Thermal conductivity and far-infrared thermal radiative properties of solids are critical issues in many modern and emerging applications such as thermal management, electronics, photovoltaics, and thermoelectrics. Both properties, although seemingly unrelated, are governed in the atomic scale by the dispersion relation and relaxation time of the same thermal energy carrier called phonon. To guide the design and synthesis of these materials, it is highly desirable to predict their thermal properties from first principles, i.e., from their atomic structures without the use of adjustable parameters. However, existing classical interatomic potentials are inaccurate even for standard materials such as silicon and carbon since the potentials were not intended for the purpose of thermal transport modeling. For most other solids, the classical potentials haven't been developed yet, making the prediction of their thermal transport properties impossible. Therefore, it is the objective of this proposal to formulate new methodologies that can develop accurate interatomic potentials or can completely bypass the use of classical potentials, for thermal property prediction. Toward this goal, two multiscale multiphysics methods will be developed in parallel. In the first method, first principles calculations will be used to develop accurate classical interatomic potentials that are intentionally optimized for thermal transport modeling, and the potentials will then be employed in classical MD to predict thermal conductivity. In order to bypass the challenging and tedious potential development process, the second method will introduce a new tight-binding molecular dynamics (TBMD) method to produce the trajectory of atoms, which will then be used in phonon spectral analysis to obtain spectral phonon relaxation time as well as thermal conductivity and radiative properties. The predictive power will be demonstrated first on standard materials such as silicon, and then on a range of important but complex thermoelectric and photovoltaic materials, including Bi2Te3 and GaAs bulk and nanomaterials.

The intellectual merit of the proposal centers around fundamentally new prediction methods based on first principles for both thermal conductive and radiative properties. The tight binding MD together with phonon spectral analysis will revolutionize thermal transport property prediction of a wide range of materials of technological importance, on which atomic scale prediction was not possible before due to the lack of empirical interatomic potentials. The methods will also be used on practically important thermoelectric and photovoltaic nanomaterials, including Bi2Te3 and GaAs, for the first time to guide experimental synthesis.

The research effort will impact thermal science and education/outreach programs. The new prediction methods will be of broad interest due to their generality. Important applications, including thermal management, thermoelectrics, electronics, and photovoltaics will benefit from the new insights generated using these methods. Under-represented and undergraduate students will continue to be involved in research. A key education/outreach component would be the dissemination of the research and education codes resulted from this project to nanoHUB and thermalHUB for general public use. Comprehensive documentation, online lectures, and tutorials explaining the codes will be provided. These materials will be of wide interest in the PI's field given the new capabilities they provide.

por.por_cntn:
Thermal conductivity prediction methods are important for understanding and discovering novel materials with desired thermal performance. For example, high thermal conductivity is desirable for thermal management while low thermal conductivity is required for thermoelectrics. In crystals, heat is carried primarily by phonons, quanta of vibrations of atoms. Similar to photons, phonons have different frequencies and wave vectors. Knowledge of phonon properties is crucial for identifying dominant phonon modes for thermal transport and for designing effective structures or phonon barriers for thermal transport control.

In this project, two atomic level prediction methods, i.e., first principles perturbation theory and molecular dynamics (MD), have been advanced to address the fundamental as well as emerging questions of thermal transport in broad range of materials. Phonon engineering is then applied to manipulate the thermal transport in nanomaterials.

First of all, the perturbation theory has been advanced to predict the phonon dispersion and relaxation time spectra of solids. In past decades, the perturbation theory has achieved great success in predicting thermal properties, whereas the prediction was limited to the lowest order of anharmonicity, i.e., three-phonon scattering, and thus the results could not match well with experiment in many cases. The calculation of higher-order phonon scattering, i.e., four-phonon scattering, has been a longstanding challenge. We have developed the formalism and realized the rigorous calculation of four-phonon scattering rate. By investigating bulk argon, diamond, silicon, germanium, and boron arsenide, we have found the key features of four-phonon scattering rate as follows: (1) It increases quadratically with temperature, in contrast to the linear relation for three-phonon scattering rate; (2) it is more important in more strongly anharmonic bulk materials; (3) it increases quartically with frequency. The thermal conductivity of Lennard-Jones argon is reduced by more than 60% at 80 K when four-phonon scattering is included. For Si and diamond, including four-phonon scattering resistance gives ~20-30% reduction in thermal conductivity at temperatures ~1000 K, bringing prediction in agreement with experiment throughout the entire temperature range considered. Surprisingly, four-phonon scattering is crucial for zincblende boron arsenide, a material predicted to have higher thermal conductivity than diamond so a promising heat sink material. Four-phonon scattering is found to reduce its thermal conductivity substantially, by 37% even at room temperature. The relatively strong four-phonon scattering in BAs originates from its weak three-phonon scattering. These conditions do not as strictly restrict the available scatterings for four-phonon process. We have also examined four-phonon scattering in graphene, a two-dimensional material with many unique properties and promising applications. The reflection symmetry in single-layer graphene (SLG) is found to block fewer four-phonon processes than three-phonon processes, especially for the ZA phonon branch. As a result, the thermal conductivity is significantly reduced after including four-phonon scattering.

Molecular dynamics (MD) is another approach to predict the spectral phonon properties of solids. Normal mode analysis (NMA) based on equilibrium MD is one such example, which can calculate the phonon dispersion and relaxation time spectra. We have proved both analytically and numerically that the phonon eigenvector is not necessary in the frequency-domain NMA. Then, we have adopted it to investigate mode-wise phonon properties of defected graphene, and found that phonon-defect scattering rate has a much weaker frequency dependence than the traditionally used dependence.

We have manipulated the thermal transport using phononic engineering by creating periodic pores. The interference of phonon waves build up a coherent transport with a long MFP throughout the lattice. As an example, we studied the graphene nanomesh (GNM) systematically by using MD simulations. The phononic structure substantially reduces the thermal conductivity. We also find that the phonon coherence in two dimensional superlattice GNM indeed exists, but not as important as in the one dimensional superlattices. To manipulate the thermal transport especially for thermoelectrics, another important approach is nanostructure engineering, which can effectively block phonons and substantially reduce the lattice thermal conductivity without degrading the electrical transport. We have investigated the nanostructuring effect on the thermal conductivities of Bismuth telluride based nanocomposites. Due to the fact that their phonon MFP is shorter than electron MFP, nanostructuring is found to benefit zT in these nanocomposites only when the lattice contributes a small portion to the total thermal conductivity. This finding is in contrary to the prevailing general notion that nanostructuring enhances zT when phonons dominate the thermal conductivity.

The results of this project has been used into the PI’s graduate course. Three PhD students (including one female PhD student) and three undergraduate students have been involved in the research. A research simulation tool has been deployed to nanoHUB. Twenty journal papers have been published or accepted to date for this project, and three journal papers have been submitted or in preparation. Twelve invited talks in universities or conferences related to this work have been given.
